dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royal sits at the head of a long table. He is surrounded his children. Chas is twelve, with curly hair, dressed in a black suit tie. Margot is ten, with a barrette in her hair, wearing knitted LaCoste dress and penny loafers. Richie is eight, with long hair, parted on the side, dressed in a Bjorn Bo style tennis outfit with a headband. Chas wears a blank expression, Margot looks as if she is about to cry, and Richie has tears all over his face.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Are you getting divorced?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (gently) At the moment, no. But it doesnвЂ™t look good.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Do you still love us?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Of course, I do.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (pointedly) Do you still love Mom? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Very much. But she asked me to leave, and I had to respect her position on the matter.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Was it our fault?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (long pause) No. Obviously, we had to make certain sacrifices as a result of having children, but no. Lord, no.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: WhyвЂ™d she ask you to leave?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (sadly) I donвЂ™t really know any more. Maybe I wasnвЂ™t as true to her as I couldвЂ™ve been.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Well, she says --

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s not rehash it, Chassie. An Indian man with salt-and-pepper hair, dressed in pink pants, a white shirt and a white apron, comes in from the kitchen with a Martini on a tray. He is Pagoda.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They were never legally divorced. Pagoda hands Royal the Martini.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Thanks, Pagoda. INT. HALLWAY. DAY. A gallery of the childrenвЂ™s art, done mostly in crayon, with beautiful frames and careful lighting. The subject matter includes: spaceships, wild animals, sailboats, motorcycles, and war scenes with tanks and paratroopers. A stuffed and mounted boarвЂ™s head with its teeth bared in the stairwell. A label on it says вЂњWild Javelina, An Mountains.вЂќ Under the stairs there is a telephone room size of a closet. Old messages are tacked to the walls, a the childrenвЂ™s heights are marked on the door frame. A thirty-three-year-old woman with a scarf around her nec and sunglasses on top of her head talks on a rotary telephone. She is Etheline. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie sits on her lap reading an Atlas of the World. Mar sits on a foot-stool reading The Cherry Orchard. Chas sta in the doorway with a slip of blue paper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Etheline Tenenbaum kept the house and raised the children, and their education was her highest priority. Etheline says into the telephone:

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™1l hold, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I need $187.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (pause) Write yourself a check. Chas hands Etheline the slip of blue paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheque made out in the amount of $187. Etheline signs i

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Chas taking back the cheque. Etheline says into the telephone: ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) Bene. Si. Grazie mille. Etheline hangs up. There is a schedule of activities -- guitar, ballet, yoga, scuba-diving -- written on a chalkb behind her and divided into columns labelled Chas, Richie Margot. She changes an Italian lesson from 4:30 to 5:30.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She wrote a book on the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A copy of Etheline TenenbaumвЂ™s book, Family of Geniuses the dust jacket there is a photograph of the three childr conducting a press conference in a room crowded with journalists. It appears to have been published in the lat seventies.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The press conference. Chas points to a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: The gentleman in the blue cardigan, please. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Thank you. I have a two-part question.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Go ahead. INT. CHASвЂ™ BEDROOM. DAY. ChasвЂ™ room looks like a businessmanвЂ™s office, except very small and has bunk beds. There is a desk with an App II computer and an electric coffee pot on it. There is a water cooler in the corner, with a paper cup dispenser. Chas stands talking on the telephone while Etheline bring his lunch on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Chas Tenenbaum had, since elementary school, taken most of his meals in his room, standing up at his desk with a cup of coffee, to save time. On a shelf in an alcove there are ten cages connected together by plastic tubes. White mice with tiny black spo all over them race around outside the cages. Chas feeds o of them a drop of blue liquid from a test tube. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) In the sixth grade, he went into business, breeding dalmation mice, which he sold to a pet shop in Little Tokyo. There are twenty-five pinstriped suits in boysвЂ™ size tw and an electric tie rack hanging in the closet. Chas push a button on the tie rack and the ties glide along a track NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) He started buying real estate in his early teens and seemed to have an almost preternatural understanding of international finance. There are a small weightlifting bench and punchbag in the corner. There is a set of exercise charts neatly drawn wi felt-tip pen tacked on the wall. Chas bench-presses about fifty pounds on a small barbell. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) He negotiated the purchase of his fatherвЂ™s summer house on EagleвЂ™s Island. EXT. BACKYARD. DAY. A house in the country. Chas crouches in the bushes with BB gun. Across the lawn, he sees two younger boys with BB guns drop down from a tree. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the boys is Richie, and the other has nearly-white blond hair. He is Eli. He wears Apache warpaint. Chas gets Richie in his sights.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Hold it, Chassie. Chas freezes. He looks up and sees Royal watching from th roof with a BB gun trained on him. Royal is dressed in kh pants, sunglasses and no shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: What are you doing? YouвЂ™re on my team!

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (hesitates) There are no teams. Royal fires. Chas screams and fires back as Royal scrambl away, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The BB was still lodged between two knuckles in ChasвЂ™ left hand. INT. MARGOTвЂ™S BEDROOM. DAY. The walls of MargotвЂ™s room are red, with little running zebras painted all over them. There is a collection of African masks hanging in the corner. Margot sits at a sma metal stand, typing on an IBM typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Margot Tenenbaum was adopted at the age of two. Her father had always noted this when introducing her.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A cocktail party. Royal introduces Margot to a group of elderly men in black tie.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: This is my adopted daughter, Margot Tenenbaum. Margot nods politely.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A wall filled with bookshelves. There are thousands of bo of plays. Margot takes out a copy of The Iceman Cometh.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was a playwright and won a Braverman Grant of fifty-thousand dollars in the ninth grade. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a mock-up of a stage set for a play that appears have taken place in a network of tree houses on a tropica island. Margot places a tiny canoe beneath a palm tree. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) She and her brother Richie ran away from home one winter and camped out in the African Wing of the Public Archives. EXT. MUSEUM. DAY. Richie and Margot sit on a bench in front of a large Goth building. Richie has on a small backpack with a sleeping attached to it. Margot carries a small red suitcase. They both look extremely dishevelled and tired. A single-file line of students in Catholic school uniform goes past them following a museum guide. Eli is at the en of the line. He stops and stares at Margot and Richie.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Eli.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: You said I could run away, too.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: No, I didnвЂ™t. And donвЂ™t tell anybody you saw us.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Richie and Margot sharing a Boy Scout sleeping bag on a b in a gallery of wildlife dioramas in a darkened museum. Margot reads a book about sharks by the light of a flashlight. Richie is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Four years later, she disappeared alone for almost two weeks and came back with half a finger missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of knitted gloves. One finger has been clipped off the middle knuckle and is being sewn up. INT. RICHIEвЂ™S BEDROOM. DAY. RichieвЂ™s room is in the attic. There are a chemistry se drum set and a long shelf filled with tennis trophies. Richie sits on the edge of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Richie Tenenbaum had been a champion tennis player since the third grade. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are thousands of Matchbox cars arranged on every available inch of space on tables, desks and window sills Richie parks a little Maserati next to a dune buggy. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) He turned pro at seventeen and won the U.S. Nationals three years in a row. There is a ham radio set in the corner of the room. Richi sits at the console wearing a set of headphones. There is map of the world on the wall, with colored pins stuck in different cities. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) He kept a studio in the corner of the ballroom but had failed to develop as a painter.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A ballroom with vaulted ceilings and a giant chandelier o the top floor of the house. One corner is filled with seventeen almost identical portraits of Margot looking ov the top of a book with an irritated expression. Etheline helps Richie hang a new portrait among the others. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) On weekends, Royal took him on outings around the city. EXT. STREET. DAY. Royal and Richie stand among a group of Puerto Rican men two large, vicious-looking pit bulls with scars all over snarl at each other. Royal yells along with the others:

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Vamanos! Andale! Royal throws a fifty-dollar bill into a pile of money on sidewalk. Richie throws in a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These invitations were never extended to anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The second floor of the Tenenbaum house. Chas sits alone one window. Margot sits alone in the next. They both watc as Royal and Richie get out of a gypsy cab in front of th house, sharing a bag of peanuts and laughing. There is a slightly run-down thirty-five-story apartment building across the street. Eli sits alone in a window.  INT. APARTMENT. DAY. A two-room apartment with a crucifix on the wall. Eli finishes making his bed and folds it into the couch. An elderly woman works at a sewing machine in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: RichieвЂ™s best friend Eli Cash lived with his aunt in a building across the street. EXT. STREET. DAY. Eli walks up the front steps of the Tenenbaum house and r the doorbell. He wears a set of house keys on a string around his neck. Pagoda opens the door. He is dressed in pajamas, slippers and a bathrobe. He lets Eli inside.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was a regular fixture at family gatherings, holidays, mornings before school and most afternoons.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The Tenenbaum house at night. There are strings of colore lights glowing around the front door and white paper bags with candles in them on the steps. Royal rings the front doorbell. He carries a small package wrapped in red-and-p striped paper with a white ribbon on it. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) The three Tenenbaum children performed MargotвЂ™s first play on the night of her eleventh birthday. INT. BALLROOM. NIGHT. There are twenty eleven-year-olds wearing party hats. Margot, Chas and Richie are in costumes. Margot is a zebr Chas is a bear and Richie is a leopard. Eli is dressed in pajamas. Royal sits at a table with them, drinking a glas of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They had agreed to invite their father to the party. There is a small stage-set across the room for a play tha appears to have taken place on a ship.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™d you think, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: It didnвЂ™t seem believable to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chas looks at Margot. She is silent. Royal says to Eli: ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Why are you wearing pajamas? Do you live here?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: He has permission to sleep over. Royal shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Did you think the characters were --

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: What characters? It was just a bunch of little kids dressed in animal costumes.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Goodnight, everyone. Margot quickly collects her unopened presents from the ta She puts RoyalвЂ™s aside and sets it in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Sweetie. DonвЂ™t get mad. ThatвЂ™s just one manвЂ™s opinion. The lights go down. Royal looks across the room. Etheline stands in the doorway with a birthday cake on a tray. The candles are lit. She looks furious. Pagoda stands at the light switch. Everyone begins to sing вЂњHappy Birthday.в Margot walks out of the room, and the singing disintegrat

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: He had not been invited to any of their parties since. Etheline blows out the candles. EXT. ROOF. DAY. There is a large antenna for RichieвЂ™s ham radio and a w coop with a falcon in it. The falcon has a hood over its eyes. Richie opens the coop, carefully removes the falcon hood, and feeds him some sardines from a tin.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In fact, virtually all memory of the brilliance of the young Tenenbaums had been erased by two decades of betrayal, failure and disaster. Richie carries the falcon on his arm to the edge of the r

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Go, Mordecai. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The falcon spreads its wings and lunges into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The names of each of our characters and the names of the actors playing them appear over the following shots.) Royal Tenenbaum sits in a chair in his hotel suite with n shirt on and a towel wrapped around his face. A woman ina white apron lifts off the towel, and Royal looks in the mirror. He is now sixty-six, with grey hair, white at the temples, worn very long in the back. He is getting a faci and there are strips of blue cellophane covering his face The woman quickly peels them away and begins to massage h temples. Royal lights a cigarette at the end of a three-i holder. Etheline Tenenbaum draws eyeliner around her eyes in the dressing mirror. She is fifty-five and has long, black ha with one silver streak that runs through it. She wears a pink slip and a gold locket. The wall behind her is fille with portraits of tribesmen and native warriors from arou the world. She holds up a pair of prescription sunglasses and looks at herself. She lowers them and does her lipsti Chas Tenenbaum shaves in the locker room of a boxing gym. Steam fills the air. He is thirty-six and in top fighting condition. Ari and Uzi Tenenbaum are on either side of hi They are eight and ten. They are also shaving, but with n blades in their razors. All three have extremely curly bl hair. Margot Tenenbaum is at a hairdresserвЂ™s with three peopl working on her at once. She is thirty-four. Her hair is being dyed, and there are little clamps and bits of foil twisted into it. She is smoking a cigarette, and she blow puff of smoke as the hair dryer is lowered onto her head. She holds an open copy of a book of plays by George Berna Shaw. She has one fake finger made of wood. Eli Cash is in the fitting room of a clothing store havin white buckskin jacket with fringe taken in. A tailor pull at the hem of the jacket and sticks pins in the sleeves. tailorвЂ™s helper brings Eli a cup of tea and some cucumb sandwiches. Eli picks out a sandwich. A second helper han him a short-brimmed Stetson cowboy hat. He puts it on at angle and stares at himself. Releigh St. Clair brushes his teeth with an electric toothbrush in a very small, white-tiled bathroom. He has full, gray beard and round glasses, and he is dressed in silk pajamas with white piping. He stops suddenly, picks a tape recorder off the edge of the sink, and excitedly dictates something into it. He puts the tape recorder bac on the sink and starts brushing his teeth again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Henry Sherman stands in front of a mirrored wall ina vestibule of his building. He is a tall black man, fifty- years old, with grey hair and a moustache. He wears a dou breasted navy blazer. He carefully folds a checkered handkerchief and tucks it into his breast pocket. There i hand-lettered sign regarding trash and recycling taped to wall behind him, underneath a row of mailboxes. It is sig H. Sherman, the Landlord, in red ink. Richie Tenenbaum looks at himself in the mirror in his stateroom on board an ocean liner. He is thirty-two, with long hair, parted on the side, and a beard. He wears a kh suit, a striped tennis shirt, a headband, and penny loafe The ocean goes by at a fast clip in the porthole behind h A towel on the dresser says The Cote dвЂ™Ivoire in red stitching. He takes out a little camera. He points it at his reflection, smiles sadly, and takes a picture of hims He puts the camera back into his pocket and goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 22 of The Royal Tenenbaums. It says вЂњChapter Two.в INT. HOTEL ROOM. DAY. RoyalвЂ™s suite at the Lindbergh Palace Hotel. There are shelves full of law books and hundreds of spy novels in stacks on the floor. There is a set of Encyclopedia Britannica, an exercise bicycle and a Xerox machine. Royal lies on his stomach on a massage table getting a massage from a young Asian woman. The manager of the hote stands in front of Royal with a piece of paper in his han

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve been instructed to refuse any further charges on your room account and to direct you in writing to please vacate the premises by the end of the month. The manager hands Royal the piece of paper. Royal points the masseuse.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: What about Sing-Sang? I owe her a hundred. The manager looks to the masseuse.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Royal had lived in the Lindbergh Palace Hotel for twenty-two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A letter typed on Lindbergh Palace Hotel stationary. It begins: Dear Mr. Tenenbaum, In light of your continuing failure to remit any form of payment, we have no --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The masseuse. She does not appear to understand English.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Can you pay her in cash? Royal shakes his head. The manager hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was a prominent litigator until the mid-eighties, when he was disbarred and briefly imprisoned.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Royal standing in the window looking out at the falling s as Sing-Sang folds up the massage table behind him. He lights a cigarette. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) No one in his family had spoken to him in three years. INT. RADIO ROOM. DAY. The radio room on board the Cote d'Ivoire. There are computer terminals, short-wave radios, maps on the walls, a crew of technicians in white uniforms. There is a mist outside the window, and an oil tanker in the distance. The radio operator finishes typing a message into a keybo and looks up to Richie.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Read it back to me so far, Pietro.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Dear Eli, IвЂ™m in the middle of the ocean. I havenвЂ™t left my room in four days. IвЂ™ve never been more lonely in my life, and I think IвЂ™m in love with Margot. The radio operator looks to Richie. Richie nods.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: New paragraph. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Richie takes a sip of a Bloody Mary.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Richie had retired from professional tennis at twenty-six. His last match had been widely discussed in the media.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A copy of the Sporting Press magazine. On the cover, ther is a photograph of Richie standing at the baseline of a tennis court. He wears no shoes and only one sock, and th are tears all over his face. The stands behind him are filled with confused fans. A caption across the page says вЂњMeltdown!вЂќ And, in smaller letters, вЂњTenenbaum suf match nervous collapse in the semis at Windswept Fields.в

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Richie dictating to the radio operator.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Your friend, Richie. End of letter. Richie signs a slip of paper and hands it to the radio operator. He wraps a scarf around his neck and goes out t door.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For the past year he had been traveling alone on an ocean liner called the Cote dвЂ™ Ivoire and had seen both poles, five oceans, the Amazon and the Nile. INT. LIBRARY. NIGHT. Eli stands at a podium reading from a book to a crowded audience. A telegram marked вЂњShip to ShoreвЂќ is tucked his coat pocket. His voice is quietly dramatic.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: The crickets and the rust-beetles scuttled among the nettles of the sagethicket. Vamanos, amigos, he whispered, and threw the busted leather flintscraw over the loose weave of the saddlecock. And they rode on in the friscalating dusklight. Eli looks up. He closes his book. The audience applauds uproariously.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Eli was an assistant professor of English Literature at Brooks College. The recent publication of his second novel -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A copy of Eli CashвЂ™s latest book, Old Custer. On the du jacket there is an illustration of an Indian in warpaint a long, bloody knife clasped between his teeth and a yell scalp hanging from his hand. INT. LOBBY. NIGHT. Eli walks among the card catalogues surrounded by a crowd admirers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- had earned him a sudden, unexpected literary celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Eli standing near the circulation desk with a group of professors drinking cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Well, everyone knows Custer died at Little Bighorn. What this book presupposes is: (tentatively) maybe he didnвЂ™t? Eli shrugs and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Eli placing a call from a pay phone in the lobby. He unfo a newspaper clipping and looks at it while he waits. He s suddenly into the receiver: ELI (CONTвЂ™D) Let me ask you something. Why would a reviewer make the point of saying someoneвЂ™s not a genius? I mean, do you think IвЂ™m especially not a genius? IsnвЂ™t that -- Someone gives Eli a book to sign. He scribbles his name o it and hands it back without looking. He says sadly: ELI (CONTвЂ™D) You didnвЂ™t even have to think about it, did you? INT. BATHROOM. NIGHT. The bathroom of MargotвЂ™s and RaleighвЂ™s apartment. Mar sits Indian-style on the counter painting her toenails re and talking on the telephone. There are cotton balls betw her toes, and she has a towel wrapped around her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hot water runs full blast in the bathtub. A little black- white television set is tuned in to the six oвЂ™clock new the sound turned off. Margot whispers into the telephone:

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Well, I just donвЂ™t use that word lightly. Margot takes a drag of a cigarette balanced at the edge o the sink. There is knock on the door. Margot does not loo up.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go, Eli. Margot hangs up the telephone. There is another knock.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Margot? Raleigh has an English accent with a lisp. Margot answers without taking the cigarette out of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: May I come in, please? Margot puts out her cigarette. She waves the smoke away, turns on a little electric fan, and sprays perfume into t air with an atomizer. She reaches over and unlocks the do with her foot. Raleigh cracks open the door and looks inside. He is wear red pajamas and a camelвЂ™s-hair bathrobe. He seems worri and intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Margot was married to the writer and neurologist Raleigh St. Clair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A copy of Raleigh St. ClairвЂ™s latest book, The Peculiar degenerative Inhabitants of the Kazawa Atoll. On the dust jacket, there is a photograph of Raleigh -- dressed in a Speedo, with goggles on top of his head -- on a beach, standing next to a Kasawa. The Kasawa stares at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Raleigh looking in the bathroom doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: How are you, my darling? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you. Margot blows on her toenails.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: You must eat something. Shall I make your dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Margot taps her fingers on the counter. The wooden one ma a clicking sound. She looks to Raleigh. Raleigh hesitates He goes out suddenly and closes the door. Margot reaches over with her foot and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was known for her extreme secrecy. For example, none of the Tenenbaums knew she was a smoker, which she had been since the age of twelve. Margot opens a box of Q-Tips. There is a cigarette hidden inside. She takes it out and lights it. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) Nor were they aware of her first marriage and divorce to a recording artist in Jamaica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A remaindered copy of Desmond Winston Manchester XIвЂ™s L record Dynamite Stick. On the sleeve there is a photograp of five Rastafarians standing in front of a metal shack. younger Margot stands behind them partly hidden in the do frame. She is dressed in a string bikini. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) She kept a private studio in Mockingbird Heights under the name Helen Scott. INT. STUDIO. DAY. A small room with one wooden chair and a metal stand with IBM electric typewriter on it. There are posters for seve of MargotвЂ™s plays leaning against the walls. The titles include: Static Electricity, Erotic Transference and Nakedness Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She had not completed a play in seven years.  17. INT. RALEIGHвЂ™S LABORATORY. DAY. RaleighвЂ™s basement. Raleigh sits at a table, across fro fifteen-year-old boy in a plaid fishing hat with вЂњDudle stitched across the front. Raleigh is dressed in a turtleneck shirt and a corduroy blazer with suede patches the elbows. The boy has an earphone in his ear. He wears Henry Aaron-style flip-up sunglasses. Raleigh and Dudley both have a set of building blocks in front of them. RaleighвЂ™s are arranged in the shape of a symmetrical cross. DudleyвЂ™s are strewn out randomly. A cardboard screen stands in between the two sets of blocks Raleigh says into his tape recorder:

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Seventeen October. Third examination of Dudley Heinsbergen. Raleigh lifts the cardboard screen and looks to Dudley. RALEIGH (CONTвЂ™D) All right, Dudley. Make yours look like mine. Dudley sets to work, moving his blocks around slowly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: RaleighвЂ™s next book was on the subject of a condition he called HeinsbergenвЂ™s Syndrome. Dudley finishes arranging his blocks into the shape of a sided octagon with branches coming out of it.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Done. Raleigh begins to laugh quietly. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: My goodness. How interesting. How bizarre.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Raleigh sitting in a corner. Dudley stands on the far sid of the room misspelling words on a chalkboard. Raleigh whispers into his tape recorder: RALEIGH (CONTвЂ™D) Dudley suffers from a rare disorder combining the symptoms of amnesia, dyslexia and color-blindness, with a highly acute sense of hearing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dudley turns around suddenly and frowns. RALEIGH (CONTвЂ™D) There is also evidence of --

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not color-blind, am I? Raleigh looks to Dudley. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m afraid you are. INT. CHASвЂ™ APARTMENT. NIGHT. AriвЂ™s and UziвЂ™s bedroom. It is perfectly neat and org like a military barracks. There are night lights in every socket. There are two fire extinguishers and a large firs aid kit mounted on the wall. There is a turtle in a fish tank in the corner. Ari and Uzi are sound asleep in their bunk beds. Chas stands in the doorway. His expression is blank. In o hand, he holds a small tape recorder. In the other hand, holds a fishing lantern. He turns on the lantern, which begins blinking rapidly in strobe effect. He presses play on the tape recorder, whic blasts a recording of a police siren at full volume. He yells at the top of his lungs:

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Fire alarm! Ari! Uzi! lLetвЂ™s go! Look alive! Ari bolts out of the top bunk. He is shirtless and has on pajama bottoms. He puts on a pair of cleats and grabs the turtle out of the fish tank. Uzi sits up. He looks half asleep. Chas runs around the room, tipping over chairs an blasting the tape recorder. He looks to Uzi. He screams: CHAS (CONTвЂ™D) Uzi! LetвЂ™s go! INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT. Ari presses the button for the elevator and waits. The apartment is extremely large and spare. It looks like a museum.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ChasвЂ™ wife, Rachael, was killed ina plane crash the previous summer. Chas and Uzi rush into the hallway. Uzi has on a pajama t and underwear. Chas yells to Ari: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: No elevators! ThereвЂ™s a fire! INT. STAIRWELL. NIGHT. They race down the stairs. Chas picks up Uzi. UZzI What about Buckley?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: You forgot him. Uzi starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slide projected onto a screen. Ari and Uzi and their mother stand in front of a small plane outside a hangar. mother has on sunglasses with a scarf tied over her hair. The wind blows her dress sideways, and she is laughing. T boys wear camp shorts and no shirts. Uzi is doing a karat stance. There is a beagle looking out of the window of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Chas and their two sons, Ari and Uzi, were also on the flight and survived, as did their dog, who was discovered in his cage several thousand yards from the crash site.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A dogвЂ™s cage upside down in the desert surrounded by sc of metal and clothing. A cloud of smoke billows in the distance. INT. BATHROOM. NIGHT. The beagle is asleep next to the bathtub on a little bed вЂњBuckleyвЂќ written on it. He looks very old and has wh around his eyes. His breathing is wheezy. ChasвЂ™ siren c be heard in the distance outside the window. It stops. EXT. SIDEWALK. NIGHT. Chas, Ari and Uzi stand on the sidewalk, looking up at th building. The street is deserted. The tape recorder has been turned off. The lantern is still blinking. Chas turns off the lantern and presses stop on his stopwa

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Four minutes and forty-eight seconds. WeвЂ™re all dead. Burned to a crisp. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chas shakes his head. He looks disoriented and weak.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Over the last six months, he had become increasingly concerned with their safety. Uzi is still crying. UZzI We left Buckley. Chas rubs his eyes and his temples. He says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: It doesnвЂ™t matter. Chas sits down on the sidewalk. Ari and Uzi look scared. The doorman watches uneasily from the lobby. INT. ETHELINEвЂ™S STUDY. DAY. The walls of EthelineвЂ™s study are filled with pre-Colum art and primitive tools and weapons. There are shelves fu of hundreds of bones and bits of pottery with little numb painted on them. There are stacks of National Geographics the floor. A human skeleton hangs on a stand in the corne

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Etheline became an archaeologist and had overseen excavations for the Department of Housing and the Transit Authority. The back doors are open on to the garden. Pagoda sits on bench outside, peeling potatoes, listening to a Walkman w headphones. His hair is now white. Etheline is at her desk studying an arrowhead while Henry sits next to her. He is working on her taxes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Apropos of my question re: I-40 slash I- 9 adjustments. Henry stands up. He seems very nervous. Etheline looks up at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She taught bridge class twice a week with her friend and business manager, Henry Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A copy of Henry ShermanвЂ™s book, Accounting for Everythi caption at the top of the cover says вЂњA Guide to Person Finance.вЂќ It appears to have been published in the late sixties.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Henry looking down at Etheline.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It would probably be advantageous for your marital status to be legally established as single, in light of the circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I mean for tax purposes.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (pause) But I thought it was --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Etheline?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Will you marry me? Pagoda stops peeling the potatoes. He takes off one ear o his headphones. Etheline puts on her prescription sunglasses. HENRY (CONTвЂ™D) I love you. Did you already know that?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: No, I didnвЂ™t. Henry nods calmly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Since her separation from her husband, she had had many suitors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large man stands on a glacier in Antarctica with pengui behind him. He wears a hooded fur coat and has ice frozen into his beard. He checks the elevation with a compass. A title identifies him as Neville Smythe-Dorleac. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: An Asian man in a tweed suit and large, perfectly round glasses on a settee in a room filled with avant-garde furniture and sculpture. He has several sets of blueprint under his arm. A title identifies him as Yasuo Oshima. A white-haired man sits in a directorвЂ™s chair on a soun stage, surrounded by extras dressed as futuristic earthli and aliens. He has a strong, weathered face and wears a safari jacket. A title identifies him as Franklin Benedic

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Henry looking down at Etheline. He has two bandaged shavi cuts, and a safety pin holds his glasses together. NARRATOR (CONTвЂ™D) -- but had not considered a single one until this moment. Etheline starts to say something. She hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: This isnвЂ™t really a tax issue, is it?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (pause) ThatвЂ™s true. I donвЂ™t know why I put it that way. Etheline smiles slightly. She takes HenryвЂ™s hand.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Let me think about it, Henry. Pagoda frowns. INT. TELEPHONE ROOM. DAY. Pagoda places a call.

dialogues.speaker: PAGODA
dialogues.text: Hello, please. Tell Mr. Royal this is the Pagoda. INT. ELEVATOR. DAY. Royal rides down in the elevator at the Lindbergh Palace. is dressed in a gray double-breasted Savile Row pinstripe suit, a dark pink shirt, a red-and-pink-striped tie, and Aristotle Onassis-style wrap-around sunglasses. He smokes cigarette. The elevator operator has a thin, gray moustache and jet- black hair. He is Dusty. The elevator stops.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dusty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUSTY
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™ re welcome. INT. LOBBY. DAY. The elevator doors open and Royal strides out quickly. crosses through a gigantic lobby. A bellboy appears.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: ThereвЂ™s a call for you, Mr. Tenenbaum.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: A Mr. Pagoda.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™1l take it in there. Royal points to a little wood-paneled telephone booth. INT. TELEPHONE BOOTH. DAY. The telephone rings. Royal answers it.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: What do you got? EXT. CITY PARK. DAY. Royal and Pagoda stand alone in the middle of a field. light, misting rain falls.

dialogues.speaker: PAGODA
dialogues.text: The black man asks her to be his wife.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (quietly) No shit? And whatвЂ™d Ethel say?

dialogues.speaker: PAGODA
dialogues.text: She thinks about it. Royal stares off into space. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t like the sound of this one damn bit, Pagoda. I mean, Lord knows IвЂ™ve had my share of infidelities. But sheвЂ™s still my wife. (pause) And no goddamn two-bit chartered accountantвЂ™s going to change that.
He

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Page 50 of The Royal Tenenbaums. It says вЂњChapter Three INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT. The doorbell rings. Pagoda comes into the hallway and ope the front door. Uzi is on the steps with a duffel bag ove his shoulder and a stack of coloring books under his arm. Buckley is at his side. Buckley has a cold and coughs oft There is a silver BMW parked at the curb with three doors the trunk open. Chas, Ari and a uniformed driver are unpacking suitcases, blankets, boxes, clothes, toys, boxi gloves and a computer. The driver is Anwar. Chas, Ari and Uzi all wear red Adidas warm-ups.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Give us a hand, Pagoda. Pagoda frowns. He starts down the steps. INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. There are twenty people at five card tables playing bridg Most of them are in their fifties and sixties. They look very distinguished. Etheline and Henry are among them. Chas, Ari, Uzi, Anwar and Pagoda come out of the hallway cross through the living room, struggling with all of the possessions. Pagoda carries the fish tank with the turtle it. Buckley follows them. The bridge players watch strangely as they pass. Chas loo back at them but keeps moving. Etheline hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Chas? Chas stops in the doorway. Pagoda leads Ari, Uzi, Anwar a Buckley out of the room, up the stairs. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) WhatвЂ™s going on?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: We got locked out of our apartment. Etheline seems confused.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Did you call a locksmith?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Uh-huh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (pause) I donвЂ™t understand. Did you pack your bags before you got locked out? Or how did you --

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s not safe over there. Silence. Etheline looks to her guests.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a moment, please. INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT. Etheline closes the sliding door to the living room. She Chas stand alone in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: The apartment. I have to get some new sprinklers and a back-up security system installed.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: But thereвЂ™s no sprinklers here, either. Chas looks up and studies the ceiling. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Well, we might have to do something about that, too. Etheline looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Two dalmation mice chewing on a plate of hors d'oeuvres o the window sill. The bridge players watch them silently. INT. CHASвЂ™ BEDROOM. NIGHT. Ari and Uzi sit silently on the bunk beds in ChasвЂ™ room They have dark circles under their eyes and seem exhauste Chas walks around the room examining things. He looks lik a wreck, but acts incredibly cheerful, pretending not to notice how sad the boys look.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: IsnвЂ™t this great? It feels like weвЂ™re camping. Chas chuckles as he turns on his old electric tie rack. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: When are we going home? Chas sees something across the room. He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Who put that in here? There is a framed poster leading against the wall in the corner. It is a tennis-shoe advertisement with a picture Richie holding a trophy over his head, surrounded by a cheering crowd. A caption across the top says вЂњThe Baum Chas turns it around to face the wall. He kisses Ari and goodnight. CHAS (CONTвЂ™D) See you in the morning. Chas goes out the door. A moment later, he comes back in. CHAS (CONTвЂ™D) You know what? IвЂ™m going to sleep in here, and that way we can all be together. Chas spreads out a blanket on the floor and lies down. Uz comes and lies down next to him. INT. DOCTORвЂ™S OFFICE. DAY. Royal sits on the edge of an examination table with white butcher paper on it. A young doctor on a rolling stool ta RoyalвЂ™s blood pressure as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: What kind of side effects can be expected?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, thereвЂ™s a number of possibilities. Severe nausea and dizziness are standard. A certain percentage of patients may also experience seizure.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: You mean like flopping around on the floor and everything?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: In some cases. Royal nods gravely.  27. EXT. HALLWAY. DAY. Etheline and Raleigh stand outside the bathroom in Margot RaleighвЂ™s apartment. Etheline has on an overcoat and gl Raleigh knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: You have a visitor, my darling. Margot answers without opening the door:

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s me, sweetie. Silence. A key slides from under the door to EthelineвЂ™s feet. Etheline looks to Raleigh. Raleigh looks embarrasse INT. BATHROOM. DAY. Margot is in the bathtub watching Planet of the Apes on h little black-and-white television set. Etheline sits on t edge of the tub with her coat in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Raleigh says youвЂ™ve been spending six hours a day locked in here watching television and soaking in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (pause) I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Well, I donвЂ™t think thatвЂ™s very healthy, do you? Nor do I think itвЂ™s very intelligent to keep an electrical gadget on the edge of the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: I tied it to the radiator. Etheline examines the television set. There is a length o red twine wrapped around it and knotted to a pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Well, it canвЂ™t be very good for your eyes, anyway. Margot turns off the television set with her foot. She lo to Etheline. Etheline smooths back MargotвЂ™s wet hair. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) Chas came home. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (pause) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: He and Ari and Uzi are going to stay with me for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (frowns) Why are they allowed to do that?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, I donвЂ™t know, exactly. But I think heвЂ™s been very depressed ever since --

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (urgently) So am I.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (pause) So are you what? EXT. STREET. DAY. The front door of Margot and RaleighвЂ™s apartment buildi opens. Margot comes out and goes down the steps with thre suitcases and her TV. Raleigh follows her. Etheline and Dudley walk behind them. Raleigh sounds desperately unhap

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: But why is this bloody necessary?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Because IвЂ™m in a rut, and I need a change. Hang on. Margot sets down her suitcases and goes into a telephone booth with graffiti spray-painted all over it. She closes the door and makes a call. Etheline stands on the corner and raises her hand into th air. A gypsy cab pulls over. Raleigh waits uncomfortably outside the telephone booth. He watches Margot talking on the telephone. Dudley points at the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: That taxi has a dent in it. Margot comes out of the telephone booth.

dialogues.speaker: RALEIGH
dialogues.text: You donвЂ™t love me anymore, do you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: I do, kind of. I canвЂ™t explain it right now. Raleigh looks crestfallen. Margot puts her suitcases into the back seat of the taxi. Dudley continues to point at i

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Another dent here and another dent there.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (gently) IвЂ™11 call you, OK? Raleigh nods. Margot gets into the taxi. Etheline looks a Raleigh sadly. She gets into the taxi and closes the door Raleigh and Dudley watch the taxi drive away. Raleigh has tears in his eyes. Dudley takes a bite of a graham cracke INT. MARGOTвЂ™S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Margot goes into her room and sets her suitcases on the floor. She closes the door and locks it. She opens the do to the closet and turns on the light. She whispers:

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Hello? There is a rustle behind some hanging clothes. Eli looks nervously and slowly emerges. He is dressed in white brie He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Hello, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Margot and Eli in MargotвЂ™s single bed with the sheets p over their heads. Margot is eating potato chips, smoking cigarette, and watching the news on her TV with the sound turned off. ELI (CONTвЂ™D) Could we have dinner with your mother sometime? Margot frowns. She looks at Eli strangely.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I donвЂ™t know. IвЂ™d just love to see her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t think so, Eli. Eli looks disappointed. EXT. SIDEWALK. DAY. The next morning, Etheline comes out the front door of th Tenenbaum house and goes down the steps. Royal suddenly appears at her side.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: You got a minute? Etheline looks startled. She keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: I need a favor. I want to spend some time with you and the children.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Now, hold on, dammit.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Stop following me.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: I want my family back.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Well, you canвЂ™t have it. IвЂ™m sorry for you, but itвЂ™s too late. Royal hesitates for a fraction of a second.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m dying, baby. Etheline stops. She looks to Royal. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) IвЂ™m sick as a dog. IвЂ™11 be dead in six weeks. IвЂ™m dying.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Royal stares at her blankly. He nods. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) What happened? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Royal shrugs. Etheline looks stunned. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) Oh, my God. Etheline looks as if she is going to faint. Royal seems suddenly worried. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) IвЂ™m sorry. I didnвЂ™t know. Etheline cannot seem to catch her breath. Royal looks aro nervously. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) WhatвЂ™d they say? WhatвЂ™s the prognosis? Etheline begins to hyperventilate. Royal tries to calm he down.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Ethel. Etheline stumbles a step and Royal catches her. He looks scared. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Hold on. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (urgently) WhereвЂ™s the doctor? lLetвЂ™s get --

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Royal holds Etheline by the shoulders. He hesitates. He says gently, trying to comfort her: ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Listen. IвЂ™m not dying. But I need some time. Etheline looks puzzled. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) A month. Maybe two. I want us to -- Etheline slaps Royal hard in the face. She says furiously

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Ethel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Go away! Etheline turns away and walks quickly across the street.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Baby. I am dying. Etheline stops. She looks back to Royal. She can see from the look on his face that now he is telling the truth. Sh goes over to him in the middle of the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Are you or arenвЂ™t you?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (pause) Dying? Yes. INT. HENRYвЂ™S APARTMENT/ETHELINEвЂ™S TELEPHONE ROOM. DAY A telephone conversation. Henry sits at a desk in his stu There are ledger books and adding machines in front of hi and glass statues of birds and animals behind him. Etheli is in the telephone room on Archer Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Have you told your children?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: More or less.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: And are they all right?

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Hard to say. INT. 375TH STREET Y/CHASвЂ™ ROOM. DAY. A second telephone conversation. Ari talks on a pay phone next to an indoor pool. Uzi stands beside him. Each wears goggles and an orange life-jacket belted tightly. A sign the wall says вЂњWater Safety and Rescue Class, 11 a.m.вЂ sits at the desk in his bedroom on Archer Avenue. UZzI WhoвЂ™s your father?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: His nameвЂ™s Royal Tenenbaum.

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: You told us he was already dead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (hesitates) But now heвЂ™s really dying. INT. ELIвЂ™S TOWNHOUSE/MARGOTвЂ™S BATHROOM-DARKROOM. DAY. A third telephone conversation. Eli sits on a couch in fr of a painting of two men wearing ski masks riding a motorcycle chasing after a screaming girl in a bikini. He smokes a long, Moroccan-looking pipe. Margot talks on the telephone in her bathroom on Archer Avenue. There are thr bottles of developing chemicals and a photographic enlarg next to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m very sorry, Margot.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s OK. WeвЂ™re not actually related, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s true. EXT. BOAT DECK. DAY. The Cote dвЂ™Ivoire. Richie sits under a wool blanket in chaise lounge reading a telegram with вЂњShore to ShipвЂќ across the top. He looks upset. A waiter stands next to h with a pen and a pad of paper in his hand. All of the oth passengers on the deck are very elderly and have white ha

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™d like to send a response, Alberto.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Dear Mom, I received your message. IвЂ™m coming home as soon as possible. (pause) Who do I see about that? The waiter shrugs. EXT. PIER 32. DAY. The entrance to the passenger terminal for the Cote d'Ivo A sign across the glass says вЂњRoyal Arctic Line.вЂќ Ric stands on the sidewalk with his hands in his pockets as bundled-up, white-haired passengers and baggage handlers by around him. He has two small suitcases and a vinyl bag with a pouch on he side for a tennis racket. There is no racket in it. Two elderly men with white hair come over t him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN 1
dialogues.text: Can we get a picture with you, Baumer? Richie nods. One of the elderly men gives his camera to a baggage handler, and they stand next to Richie.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN 2
dialogues.text: I saw you whip Vishniac in the finals at Glenchester. You were beautiful back then. Richie smiles briefly. The baggage handler takes the picture.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN 1
dialogues.text: Thanks, Champ. The two elderly men walk away. A city bus stops at the corner. The door opens and Margot gets out. She smiles at Richie and waves. She wears a mink coat with a belt aroun it. She has on pink gloves. She walks across the sidewalk and stops ten feet in front of Richie as the bus drives a They stand there smiling at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Stand up straight and let me get a look at you. Richie stands up a little straighter and continues to loo Margot with the same smile. MARGOT (CONTвЂ™D) WhatвЂ™s so funny? Richie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, itвЂ™s nice to see you, too. Their smiles fade, and they both look cold and sad. Richi reaches out his hand. Margot goes over to him and puts he arms around him. EXT. TENENBAUM HOUSE. DAY. Margot and Richie stand on the steps in front of the hous The door opens and Etheline and Pagoda come outside and h Richie. Richie and Henry shake hands. Ari and Uzi come running out and hug Richie.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That night, Etheline found all of her children living together under the same roof for the first time in seventeen years. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chas watches from his window on the third floor. Richie looks up and sees him. Richie waves tentatively. Chas wav back without smiling. EXT. ROOF. DAWN. Richie comes out on to the roof dressed in pajamas. He op his falconвЂ™s coop. He puts his hand under the falconвЂ™ and the falcon steps on to his fist. The falconвЂ™s hood Mordecai across the front. Richie pulls a leather cord an lifts the hood off the falconвЂ™s head. He strokes the falconвЂ™s feathers and talks softly in its ear.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The next morning Richie woke at dawn. He had decided birds should not be kept in cages, fed Mordecai three sardines, and set him free.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: An hour later. Richie sits on a box on the roof eating a bowl of cereal and reading a book called Three Plays by Margot Tenenbaum. There is an empty tin of sardines at hi feet. The door to the falconвЂ™s coop is open, and the fa is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 76 of The Royal Tenenbaums. It says вЂњChapter Four. EXT. STREET. EVENING. Royal gets out of a gypsy cab in front of the Tenenbaum house. He is dressed in a white bathrobe, white pajamas a red bedroom slippers. He carries a cane, but walks across the sidewalk quickly and energetically. Pagoda waits for him at the top of the steps. They shake hands. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Pagoda opens the front door. INT. LIVING ROOM. EVENING. Royal sits on a stool across from Richie and Margot on th couch. Chas stands at a table in the corner reading Richi Atlas of the World. Royal looks to Chas. Chas looks back him but does not move. Royal looks back to Richie and Margot.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve missed the hell out of you, my darlings. You know that, donвЂ™t you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: I hear youвЂ™re dying.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: So they tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I had a good run.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: You donвЂ™t look so sick, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™ve you got?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve got a pretty bad case of cancer.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: (yawning) How long are you going to last? Royal looks across the room at Chas. Chas does not look u from his atlas.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Not long.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: A month? A year?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: About six weeks. Royal looks back to Richie and Margot. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) But let me get to the point here. The three of you and your mother are all IвЂ™ve got, and I love you more than anything. Chas laughs quietly. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Let me finish. Now, IвЂ™ve got six weeks to set things right with you, and I aim to do it. Will you give me a chance? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Do you speak for everyone?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I speak for myself.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Well, youвЂ™ve made your views known. So why donвЂ™t you let somebody else do some of the talking now?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: What do you propose to do?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Well, I canвЂ™t say, really. Make up for lost time, I suppose. But the first thing IвЂ™d like to do is take you to see your grandmother, at some point.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: (pause) I havenвЂ™t been out there since I was six.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: I havenвЂ™t been there at all. I was never invited.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Well, she wasnвЂ™t your real grandmother, so I didnвЂ™t know youвЂ™d be interested, sweetie. Anyway, youвЂ™re invited this time.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Thanks. Richie looks to Chas. He looks back to Royal.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: You know, RachaelвЂ™s buried there, too.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (pause) Who?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: My wife.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Oh. ThatвЂ™s right, isnвЂ™t it? Well, we can swing by her grave, too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chas slams the atlas shut and puts it back into the bookc He walks toward the door. Royal extends his hand as Chas walks by. Chas slaps it away and goes out of the room. Royal says to Margot and Richie: ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) IвЂ™1l be right back. INT. STAIRWAY. EVENING. Chas is already half-way to the second floor as Royal app at the bottom of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Chas? Chas stops. He looks down to Royal. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) May I see my grandsons?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Because IвЂ™d like to finally meet them. Chas scoffs at the idea and shakes his head. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) DonвЂ™t give me that guff.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I think weвЂ™1l pass. Chas walks away up the stairs. There is a clean square an hook on the wall in the stairwell, as if something has be removed. Royal frowns. He yells toward the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Pagoda! WhereвЂ™s my javelina? INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Royal stands in the living room with Richie and Margot.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™1l say goodnight to you now, children. Margot waves. Richie hugs Royal. Royal looks to be on the verge of tears. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Thank you, my sweet boy.  39. EXT. TENENBAUM HOUSE. NIGHT. Royal and Pagoda stand outside the top of the front steps Royal says quickly:

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™11 contact you in the next twelve hours and give you further instructions. Pagoda nods. A taxi stops in front of the house. RoyalвЂ™ face darkens. Henry and Etheline get out of the taxi. The each carry a playbill for a play called That Rascal. Roya clamps his hand on PagodaвЂ™s arm and lets out a slow whi ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Look at that old grizzly bear. Royal licks his fingers and smooths back his hair. He bou down the steps. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Hello, Ethel! Good evening, sir. Hold the cab, please, driver. Henry leaves the door to the taxi open.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Royal, this is Henry Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Hey, man. Lay it on me. Royal puts out his hand for Henry to give him five. Henry reluctantly slaps hands with Royal and says:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Ah, what can I say? IвЂ™m dying. Henry looks uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t pay any attention to that man, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m just kidding. Goodnight all. Royal gets into the taxi and closes the door. EXT. STREET. DAY. Margot and Eli walk together down a street with trash everywhere and abandoned cars and broken windows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Right there is where I used to go get jacked off. Margot nods. She seems distracted. ELI (CONTвЂ™D) You donвЂ™t give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m listening. (points to a deli) Right there is where you used to go get jacked off.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s right. They walk in silence for a minute. ELI (CONTвЂ™D) HowвЂ™s Richie?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (pause) I donвЂ™t know. I canвЂ™t tell.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me, either. He wrote me a letter. He says heвЂ™s in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (frowns) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (shrugs) ThatвЂ™s what he said. I donвЂ™t know how weвЂ™re supposed to take it. Hang on. They stop in front of a partially demolished building. El presses the buzzer to one of the apartments. A voice come on the call box:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Sugar, itвЂ™s Eli.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey, baby. The door buzzes open. Margot says blankly:

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: What are we doing, Eli? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: I just got to pick something up. DonвЂ™t repeat that, by the way. About Richie. It was told in confidence. Eli goes inside. Margot stands alone on the street. She looks up at the destroyed building. EXT. ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATION. DAY. A large network of pits between two brownstone townhouses There are workers digging, surveying, sketching, and shak dirt through metal hand-screens. The archaeologists crouch around Etheline while she compa a bit of soil on the end of a trowel with a color chart i handbook. She is dressed entirely in denim except for a scarf over her hair. She has on sunglasses and boots. The three archaeologists are all scruffy young men with beard

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Good. Now IвЂ™1l just remove the loose soil and note the decomposition levels. Etheline dusts off a partially unearthed skeleton. Henry appears in the background, climbing down a ladder on the side of the pit. He wears a gray wool suit and tie. He picks up a pebble off the ground and looks at it. Ethelin says to the three archaeologists: ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) These were probably slaves. Before the arrival of the --

dialogues.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
dialogues.text: What are you doing? A graduate student with a shovel is looking at Henry and frowning. Etheline and the three archaeologists turn arou and see them. GRADUATE STUDENT (CONTвЂ™D) Please, put that artifact back where you found it, sir. Henry looks embarrassed. He puts the pebble back on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Etheline and Henry walking through a trench together.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry to interrupt your work.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t be silly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to apologize for the other day. When I proposed to you.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Why? I thought it was very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Look. I know IвЂ™m not as accomplished as some of the men youвЂ™ve been involved with. Franklin Benedict and General Cartwright and your ex-husband and --

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But I feel I have just as much to offer as any of them. I know I went about it backwards, but --

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Henry, I have no interest in Frank Benedict or Doug Cartwright. I never did. Henry falls into a pit and disappears from view. Etheline does not notice this and continues walking. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) And as far as Royal is concerned, heвЂ™s the most -- Etheline stops. She looks around. She sees Henry climbing up a ladder, out of the pit. He is covered with dirt and a small twig in his hair. She rushes over to him. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) Are you all right? Henry sighs. He brushes some dirt off his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m fine. Anyway, let me know when you make up your mind. Henry starts to walk away. Etheline grabs his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: Wait a second, Henry. Henry stops. He looks to Etheline. She takes his hand and kisses it. He looks surprised. ETHELINE (CONTвЂ™D) IвЂ™m sorry. IвЂ™m very nervous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Etheline pulls the twig out of HenryвЂ™s hair.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s OK. Thank you. Why are you --

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth, I havenвЂ™t slept with a man in eighteen years. Silence. Henry nods. He puts his hand on EthelineвЂ™s che INT. MARGOTвЂ™S BEDROOM. DAY. Margot lies in her bed behind a mosquito net watching a downhill skiing competition on her portable television. Etheline stands in the doorway and says calmly:

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: I think IвЂ™m falling for Henry. Margot looks to Etheline. She pulls open the mosquito netting.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s amazing.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: What do you think of him?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (excited) I think heвЂ™s gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™11 tell you a secret. He asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (dreamily) IвЂ™m going to have a father.

dialogues.speaker: ETHELINE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, I havenвЂ™t accepted yet. Besides, you already have a father, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Not really. Plus, now heвЂ™s dying.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The hallway outside MargotвЂ™s room. Pagoda is poised in dark, watching from the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rooftop park with a chain-link fence around it. There a several fighters lifting weights and jumping rope. Ari do chin-ups from a jungle gym. Uzi does sit-ups on a mat. Buckley lays on the cement beside them. Someone whistles from behind the fence. Ari and Uzi look. It is Royal. He is inside a telephone booth with the door partly open, holding the receiver to his ear. He signals Ari and Uzi to come over. Ari frowns. He looks across the courtyard to Anwar, sitti on a bench, reading a BMW ownerвЂ™s manual. Royal ducks b into the telephone booth and holds the receiver to his ea Anwar does not look up. Ari slides down a fire-station-type pole. He and Uzi cautiously go over to the fence with Buckley. Royal hangs the receiver and comes out of the telephone booth.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s a hell of an old hound dog you got there. WhatвЂ™s he go by?

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: Buckley.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (pointing at Buckley) Buckley. Sit. Buckley sits. Royal looks impressed. He turns to Ari. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) You know who I am? Ari shakes his head. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) IвЂ™m Royal. You heard of me? Ari nods. Royal looks pleased. His expression becomes serious again. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) IвЂ™m very sorry for your loss. Your mother was a terribly attractive woman.

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: (pause) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Which one are you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: Ari.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (looks to Uzi) Uzi, IвЂ™m your granddad. UZzI Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry we havenвЂ™t gotten to know each other. I donвЂ™t get invited around much. What do you think about that, by the way? You donвЂ™t have to say anything. Royal sighs. He stares off into space. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Kind of a fuck-you to the old man, I guess. Royal looks back to Ari and Uzi. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) HowвЂ™s your daddy?

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: You think so? How oftenвЂ™s he got you working out?

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: Sixteen times a week.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Do me a favor. Tell him you want to meet me. UZzI But we just met.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: No, we didnвЂ™t. Ari and Uzi look confused. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Look. I want us to have a relationship, but weвЂ™re going to have to pull some strings to make that happen. (pause) HereвЂ™s what you tell him...  46. INT. CHASвЂ™ BEDROOM. DAY. Ari and Uzi sit across from Chas. He is behind his desk w his back turned to them. Ari and Uzi are both dressed in black Adidas warm-ups. Chas wears his red one. A technici tinkers with a large Xerox machine on the other side of t room. Another technician rolls in a crate on a dolly.

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: I bet Mom wouldвЂ™ve wanted us to meet him before he died, wouldnвЂ™t she? Chas turns his chair around and looks to Ari and Uzi. Silence. He sighs. EXT. CEMETERY. DAY. A small cemetery next to an electrical power plant. The trees are bare, and the city is across the river. Chas, A and Uzi stand together dressed in black Adidas warm-ups. Royal and Richie stand beside them. RoyalвЂ™s motherвЂ™s gravestone reads вЂњHelen OвЂ™Reilly (1909-1962) .вЂќ Epitaph: вЂњThe Salt of the Earth.вЂќ Ro places a bouquet of white flowers at the foot of the grav There are tears in his eyes. He says to Chas:

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: She was a tough old broad, wasnвЂ™t she?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: I wouldnвЂ™t know. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Oh, thatвЂ™s right. We got another body buried out here. Hang on. Take some of these. Royal takes half of the white flowers off his motherвЂ™s and hands them to Chas. Chas walks away. Silence. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) What do you think of this big old black buck moving in up there?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: (pause) Who?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Henry Sherman. You know him?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Is he worth a damn? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: I believe so. Royal nods.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Ari, Uzi and Margot standing in front of RachaelвЂ™s gravestone, which reads вЂњRachael Evans Tenenbaum (1965- 2000).вЂќ Uzi stares at MargotвЂ™s missing finger. UZzI What happened to your finger? Ari looks quickly to Uzi.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: It got chopped off by an axe. UZzI HowвЂ™d it get chopped off by --

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: Uzi. Shh.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s OK. IвЂ™11 tell you. IвЂ™m adopted. Did you know that? Uzi shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I am. And I went to find my real family when I was fourteen. They live in Indiana. EXT. FARM. DAY. A fourteen-year-old Margot stands behind a barn with a fa of blond farmers. There are a mother and father and five very young children. MargotвЂ™s hair is dyed black, and s wears a black LaCoste dress, black eyeliner, and black na polish.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Now just set one of them hickory trunks right up on top there, sister Maggie. Margot sets a log sideways on top of a wood pile. She reaches to adjust the log slightly just as the father swi an axe and chops the log in half. Everyone looks stunned. The father stares at MargotвЂ™s b hand. Margot looks to the father as if he is an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Margot, Ari and Uzi standing together.

dialogues.speaker: ARI
dialogues.text: Did you try to sew it back on?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) CouldnвЂ™t find it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Richie and Royal looking at an impressive monument in the middle of the cemetery. An inscription says: вЂњVeteran o Wars. Father of Nine Children. Drowned in the Caspian Sea

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s a hell of a damn grave. Richie nods. Royal says wistfully: ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) I wish it were mine.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Royal and Richie walking together among the gravestones. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) ItвЂ™s a shame, isnвЂ™t it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: You probably had another good two to three years of competitive play in you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Probably.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: I had a lot riding on that match, you know. Financially and personally. Richie nods. Silence. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) WhyвЂ™d you choke out there that day, Baumer?

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: (pause) I donвЂ™t know, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A television set tuned in to network coverage of a tennis match on grass courts. Richie is playing an Indian player dressed all in white. A title identifies him as Sanjay Gandhi. Gandhi serves. With a bizarre swing, Richie hits his retu directly off the court and deep into the stands. He shake his head and talks to himself. It is briefly revealed tha he is wearing no shoes and only one sock.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s seventy-two unforced errors for Richie Tenenbaum. HeвЂ™s playing the worst tennis of his life. WhatвЂ™s he feeling right now, Tex Hayward?

dialogues.speaker: TEX HAYWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know, Jim. ThereвЂ™s obviously something wrong with him. HeвЂ™s taken off his shoes and one of his socks, and - - actually, I think heвЂ™s crying. Richie is shown preparing to serve with tears all over hi face. He hesitates. He looks into the stands.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: WhoвЂ™s he looking at in the friendsвЂ™ box, Tex? Margot and Raleigh, holding hands, watch from their seats a courtside box. They look very concerned.

dialogues.speaker: TEX HAYWARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s his sister, Margot, and her new husband, Raleigh St. Clair. They were just married yesterday, Jim. Richie stares at Margot and Raleigh. He looks to Chas, wi Rachael, Ari and Uzi. He looks to Etheline. He looks to Royal in a lonely seat up in the nosebleed section. Royal stands up and walks towards the exit. Richie serves suddenly, underhand, barely tossing the bal into the air. Gandhi nails his return, and Richie attempt to play it by throwing his racket at the ball.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Royal and Richie standing together.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: I kind of disappeared after that, didnвЂ™t

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Yeah, but I understood. I know youвЂ™re not very good with disappointment. Royal nods. He kicks a pebble on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Royal scraping some dirt off of RachaelвЂ™s gravestone wi foot. Chas stands beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: You still got that little BB in your hand, Chassie? Chas looks to Royal. He holds up his hand and shows Royal little round bump between two knuckles. Royal taps it wit his finger. It moves slightly.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: WhyвЂ™d you shoot me? Silence. Royal says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: It was the object of the game, wasnвЂ™t it?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: No. We were on the same team.

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Were we? Chas does not respond. Royal sighs. ROYAL (CONTвЂ™D) Well, you sued me. Twice. And got me disbarred. But I donвЂ™t hold it against you, do I? INT. JUDGEвЂ™S CHAMBERS. DAY. A lawyer in a robe sits behind his desk. Chas and Royal a two attorneys sit across from him. A stenographer sits at metal stand, typing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And how was it possible for Mr. Tenenbaum to withdraw these funds without your written authorization?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: Objection, your honor. Now, dammit -- (CONTINUED)
ROYALвЂ™S LAWYER This isnвЂ™t a courtroom, Royal. DonвЂ™t object.

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Because I started the corporation when I was a minor, so my father was the primary signatory on most of my accounts. ChasвЂ™ attorney whispers something into his ear. CHAS (CONTвЂ™D) He also stole bonds out of my safety deposit box when I was fourteen. The judge looks to Royal. Royal looks guilty.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Royal and Chas surrounded with Ari and Uzi. Chas turns

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
dialogues.text: You think you could start forgiving me?

dialogues.speaker: CHAS
dialogues.text: Why should I?

dialogues.speaker: ROYAL
